DOC.HEAD: Stepped-Up Anti-Drug Program Allots Four-Fold Increase to California
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department announced Friday a nearly four-fold increase in federal money for anti-drug abuse programs in California in its first allocation of state aid under a stepped-up program approved by Congress. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said the money is part of the Bush administration's efforts to help communities ``attack the problem at the point of consumption.'' He said the department is urging states to incorporate recommendations of President Bush's national drug control strategy into their programs. California, the first state to receive funds for fiscal year 1990, will get $39.7 million, almost $30 million more than its 1989 grant of $10.8 million. Under a plan adopted by California, nearly 65 percent of the money will be distributed to local communities. ``The California plan was approved within two weeks of being received, and the money is being distributed in less than six weeks after the president signed the appropriations legislation,'' Thornburgh said in a statement. The department said its Bureau of Justice Assistance is receiving and reviewing grant applications from other states. Congress appropriated $395 million for the grants. The funds will enable California to continue supporting 36 projects including investigative task forces and specialized prosecution initiatives, the department said. It said part of the grant would be distributed to counties on the basis of population and severity of crime.
